question.body: What is the probability that Jim will be admitted to at least one of the two colleges?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The event “admitted to at least one of the two colleges” means admitted to College A or College B or both. You may have interpreted all of these “or” statements as meaning “addition” and calculated P(A) + P(B) + P(A and B), but this is incorrect because P(A and B) is included in P(A), as well as P(B). So P(A and B) is subtracted from P(A) + P(B) as shown in the General Addition Rule.
Not quite right. P(admitted to at least one college) = P(A or B), but the events are not disjoint. So P(A or B) is not equal to P(A) + P(B). You need to use the General Addition Rule.
Correct. P(admitted to at least one college) = P(A or B). Since the events are not disjoint, we must use the General Addition Rule. P(A or B) = 0.10 + 0.75 − 0.05 = 0.80

Incorrect. You may have used the General Addition Rule P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A and B) but calculated P(A and B) incorrectly by multiplying P(A) * P(B). This is incorrect because A and B are not independent in this situation. P(A and B) is given as 0.05, which is not equal to P(A) * P(B) = 0.10 * 0.75 = 0.075.
